adequate refrigeration facilities are provided for the storage of perishable foodstuffs; and
any room in which fruit and vegetables are stored, is adequately ventilated and equipped with heavy wire shelves and racks.

intro.p: No person who operates a nursing home may do so unless the rooms referred to in sections 87 and 88 comply with the following additional requirements:
The rooms may not be situated in, or share an entrance with, any –

content.p: ward or room used for sleeping;
sluice-room; or
toilet and urinal;
the rooms must be provided with adequate racks, shelves and other means to store bulk goods at a minimum height of 225mm above the floor;
adequate lighting and ventilation, as prescribed by the National Building Regulations and Building Standards Act, must be provided.

intro.p: Any person who operates a nursing home must ensure that–

content.p: a room or cupboard, of adequate size is set aside, to be used solely for the storage of medicines and drugs;
every room or cupboard set aside in terms of paragraph (a), is kept locked at all times except when medicines or drugs are being removed from it or returned to it; and
within that room or cupboard, a separate lockable cupboard or locker is reserved for the storage of poisons, habit-forming drugs and potentially dangerous drugs.
Any person who operates a nursing home must provide adequate apparatus for the sterilisation of instruments.
If laundering is carried out on the premises of a nursing home, this must take place in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 11.

intro.p: Any person who operates a nursing home must ensure that–

content.p: the reception room for soiled articles is used exclusively for receiving and sorting soiled articles;
a wash-hand basin, supplied with running hot and cold potable water is provided, in each reception room;
each reception room is mechanically ventilated in a manner that ensures that any air generated in the room is discharged into the atmosphere; and
a separate reception room is provided in any maternity home and used exclusively for receiving and sluicing of baby napkins.

If laundering is carried out on the premises of a nursing home, the premises that are used for such laundering must comply with the requirements for premises on which a laundry business is conducted as contemplated in section 65 of these By-laws.

intro.p: Any person who operates a nursing home must ensure that –

content.p: any storage room is used exclusively for the storage and distribution of those articles intended to be stored in such storeroom;
any storage room contains adequate moveable shelving made of impervious material;
every shelf is a minimum height of 225 mm above the floor;
containers used for the reception or conveyance of soiled or laundered articles are adequately marked so that they can be easily distinguishable from one another; and

all persons employed in any part of the laundry are provided with, and wear, caps covering their hair and clean overalls made of light-coloured material, of a design approved by an environmental health officer.

intro.p: Any person who operates a nursing home must ensure that at all times, all linen provided in the premises is –

content.p: of good quality;
maintained in good repair; and
available in a quantity adequate to ensure the prompt replacement of soiled articles.
Any person who operates a nursing home must provide an adequate number of refuse receptacles on the premises.

intro.p: No person may operate a nursing home unless –

content.p: adequate sleeping accommodation is provided for the resident nursing staff employed on the premises;

adequate arrangements are made for the separation of the sleeping accommodation of members of the staff on day duty and those on night duty, so as to avoid the undue disturbance of staff sleeping; and
a dining-room and separate recreation room is provided for the nursing staff: Provided that one room may be used as a dining and recreation room if the room is adequate for both purposes.
In this Chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates –
"child-care premises" mean premises on which child-care services are offered;

"child-care service" means any service, whether for gain or otherwise, for the reception, protection, care and bringing-up of more than six children apart from their parents, but does not include any reform school, boarding school, school hostel or any establishment which is maintained or used mainly for the tuition or training of children and which is controlled by or which has been registered or approved by the State, including a provincial administration, as contemplated in the Child Care Act, 1983 (Act No. 74 of 1983).
No person may provide a child-care service except on child-care premises which comply with the requirements of sections 101 to 116 and in terms of a permit authorising that activity.

intro.p: A child-care service may only be provided in or on premises which are located, designed, constructed, finished, equipped and in such a condition that children –

content.p: can be cared for hygienically; and
can be adequately protected against any possible public health hazard and public health nuisance.

intro.p: Child-care premises on which children under compulsory school-going age are cared for, must be provided with an indoor play area which must -

content.p: be enclosed by buildings and structures constructed of materials and in a manner that ensures the health and safety of children using that area;
have a floor which is smooth, easily washable and which prevents the permeation of dampness;

intro.p: have a play area with a minimum of 1,5 m² free unobstructed floor space per child, or 3 m² if no outdoor play area is provided, and which is divided by walls or removable partitions into separate indoor play areas in which children of the following age groups are cared for separately at all times:

content.p: 0-2 years;
2-4 years; and
4 years up to compulsory school-going age.
have an activity area of 4m² for every child of school going age catered for on the premises

intro.p: If child-care premises have an outdoor play area it must –

content.p: be free of any excavations, steps, projections, levels or any surface which may adversely impact on the health and safety of children using that area;
provide a minimum outdoor play area of 2 m² per child;
have an adequate means of enclosure and a lockable gate to prevent a child leaving the premises on his or her own and to prevent the entrance of any animal and unauthorised person; and

intro.p: have separate outdoor play areas for the following different age groups:

content.p: 0-2 years;
2-4 years;
4 years up to compulsory school- going age; and
school-going children.

intro.p: Child-care premises must have adequate toilet and wash facilities for all children with -

content.p: a ratio of not more than 15 children for each toilet or chemical toilet;
a ratio of not more than 20 children for each hand wash facility; and
a supply of hot and cold running potable water must be available at every wash-

wrapUp.p: hand basin, or if no running water is available, a minimum of 25 litres of potable water, stored in a hygienically clean container, must be available on the premises at all times.

section.heading: Toilet and wash facilities for children under the age of 2 years

intro.p: Child-care premises must provide the following additional toilet and wash facilities for children under the age of 2 years:

content.p: A separate napkin changing unit for changing the napkins of children under the age of 2 years;
adequate wash facilities to clean children wearing napkins;
adequate containers for the storage of clean and soiled napkins.

intro.p: No person may provide a child-care service unless the child-care premises comply with the following additional requirements:

content.p: Separate toilet and hand wash facilities must be provided for staff members;
no child may, at any time, have access to living quarters of staff and adequate measures must be taken to keep the living quarters separate;
an adequate sick-bay area for the treatment and care of any child who falls ill or who is injured during day care, must be provided;
an adequate method for hand washing must be provided in the sick-bay area;
an approved lockable and adequately equipped first aid unit must be provided and maintained in the sick-bay area;
an adequate office area must be provided;
an adequate kitchen area, where food is to be handled, prepared, stored and provided to children, must be provided;
the kitchen area referred to in paragraph (g) must comply with any relevant law;
a separate storage area of adequate size must be provided for the storage of indoor and outdoor play materials, equipment, stretchers, sleeping mats, bedding and linen; and
a separate designated storage facility of adequate size for the storage of the personal belongings of each child and staff member must be provided.

intro.p: Any person who provides a child-care service must provide –

content.p: adequatechild-sized seating and tables for each child;
adequate individual resting or sleeping places for each child;
an approved blanket for the individual use of each child; and
adequate indoor and outdoor play equipment for the children’s use.

intro.p: Any person who provides a child-care service for children of school-going age must provide the following after-school care facilities:

content.p: If an after-school care is provided on the same premises as for the care of children under school going age, the facilities for the two groups of children must be kept totally separate, except for the kitchen and office area;
an indoor care area of at least 1,5 m² free floor space for each child must be provided;
an outdoor play area of at least 2 m² for each child must be provided;
one toilet and one hand-wash facility must be provided for every 20 children, or part of that number, and the facilities must be separately designated for the use of each sex; and
adequate seating and tables must be provided for each child.

intro.p: Any person who provides a child-care service or is in charge of child-care premises must –
in respect of any child who becomes ill or has suffered an injury requiring medical attention –

content.p: immediately notify the parent or guardian of the child;
immediately call for medical assistance; and
provide necessary care and treatment in the sick-bay area required in terms of section 106(c);
immediately notify the Council in the event of the illness being a communicable disease;
ensure that every child has completed basic immunization schedules as considered necessary by the Council;

comply with the provisions of any relevant legislation and regulations published under the Health Act, 1977 (Act No. 63 of 1977), regarding the exclusion of children from day-care services on account of infectious diseases;
be trained in basic first aid; and
only administer medicine to a child with the written consent of that child’s parent or guardian.

intro.p: No person may provide a child-care service unless the following safety measures are complied with:

content.p: Children must be adequately protected against fires, hot water installations, electrical fittings and appliances, heating appliances and any other article, thing or substance that may be dangerous or cause injury to any child;

any slats or rails forming part of an enclosure, security gate, play pen, bed, cot or any other object or structure whatsoever, must be a minimum of 75 mm apart, must be installed and maintained in a good state of repair, and if painted, only non-toxic paint must be used;
all medicines, pesticides, detergents and other harmful substances must be stored in a locked place inaccessible to any child at all times;
no noxious or poisonous or dangerous plant or shrub may be permitted on the premises;

all animals or birds must be kept in enclosures as contemplated in chapter 15 of the by-laws and provided that no health hazard or health nuisance is created; [[Item (e) amended: Notice 2076 : 2011-08-03 PG No 167]]

no person known or suspected to be suffering from an infectious or contagious disease, and no person so suffering, may be allowed on the premises while, in the opinion of an environmental health officer, the person is capable of communicating the infectious or contagious disease to the children;
no paddling pool, swimming pool or other structure may be permitted in any child-care service without adequate fencing and a safety net;
any sandpit must be adequately covered when not in use and must be treated with a treatment agent on a regular basis; and

any other reasonable measures which may, in the opinion of an environmental health officer, be necessary to protect the children from any physical danger, must be taken by the child-care service provider on the instruction of an environmental health officer.

section.heading: General duties of a child-care service provider

intro.p: Any person who provides a child-care service must –

content.p: ensure that the children are properly cared for and supervised at all times;
maintain every part of the premises, including any equipment, in good repair and in a clean and hygienic condition at all times;
ensure that all persons on or in the premises are clean in person and clothing and are in good state of health;
ensure that no person smokes or uses any tobacco product in the presence of children;
ensure that the toys, books and other indoor play materials intended for day-to-day use are available in any indoor play area and suitably stored so that they are within easy reach of the children;

intro.p: ensure that the children are at all times under the direct supervision of an adult in the following ratio:

content.p: one adult supervisor for every 6 babies between 0-18 months;
one adult supervisor for every 12 children between 18 months and 3 years;
one adult supervisor for every 20 children between 3 and 5 years;
one adult supervisor for every 30 children between 5 and 6 years; and
one adult supervisor for every 35 children of school going age;

intro.p: if transport to or from a child care service is provided, ensure that –

content.p: the children are supervised by at least one adult apart from the driver during transport;
the doors of the vehicle are lockable so that they cannot be opened from inside the vehicle;
no children are transported in the front seat or the boot of the vehicle;
no babies are placed under the seat of a vehicle;
the vehicle is not overloaded in terms of any applicable law;
the driver of the vehicle holds a valid licence to transport the passengers; and
the vehicle is licensed and is in a road worthy condition;
when children are transported in the back of an enclosed light commercial vehicle, ensure that no exhaust fumes enter the enclosed area and that it is adequately ventilated;
if meals are provided, display a two-weekly menu that must be visible to the parents;
provide nutritionally balanced meals of adequate volume to satisfy the energy needs of the children in each age group;
provide a laundry area an adequate distance from any area used to care for children or the kitchen, if laundry is done on the premises;
provide an adequate number of bins with self-closing lids for the disposal of paper, paper towels, tissues and other waste materials, inside the premises;
provide an approved refuse area, with adequate refuse bins, for the storage of refuse pending removal;
provide each child with a towel, preferably disposable, for his or her individual use on the premises;
provide adequate individually marked pegs or hooks for each child to hang his or her towel on; and
provide an adequate and easily available supply of toilet paper, soap and tissues for the children’s use.

intro.p: Any person who provides a child-care service must ensure that –
an application form containing the following information is completed by the parent or guardian of every child when he or she is admitted to the child-care service:

content.p: The child’s name and date of birth;
the name, address and telephone number of the parent or guardian;
the place of employment and telephone number of the parent or guardian;
the name, address and telephone number of a responsible person other than the parent or guardian who may be consulted in emergencies; and
the name, address and telephone number of the child’s doctor together with permission to consult him;
all application forms are kept for a minimum period of three years from the date a child is discharged; and
the date of admission and discharge of each child is written on the relevant application form.

intro.p: Any person who provides a child-care service must keep an admission and discharge register of all children admitted to and discharged from the child-care service, in which –

content.p: the presence or absence of each child is recorded daily; and
each child’s date of birth is recorded.

intro.p: Any person who provides a child-care service must obtain a report from the parent or guardian of each child containing the following health data:

content.p: Information concerning the child’s general state of health and physical condition;
operations, illnesses and any communicable diseases which the child has suffered and the relevant dates;
details of required immunizations; and
details of allergies and any medical treatment the child may be undergoing.

Any person who provides a child-care service must keep a journal, in which any important or outstanding event, including any accident on the premises or during transportation of children, and any explanation is recorded.

Any person who provides a child-care service must keep a medical journal in which the details and quantity of any medicine given to a child is recorded, and the child-care provider must ensure that the journal is signed daily by the parent or guardian of any child to whom medicine was given.
In this Chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates -
"agricultural holding" means the same as defined in the applicable Town Planning Scheme;
"animal" means any cattle, sheep, goat, horse, mule, donkey, pig, rabbit and wild animal;
"aviary" means an enclosure used for the keeping of birds, other than poultry but does not include a portable cage;
"battery system" means the method of keeping poultry or rabbits in cages in either single rows or tier formation within a building or structure;

blockList.listIntroduction: "cattery" means premises in or upon which –

item.p: boarding facilities for cats are provided; or
cats are bred for commercial purposes;

content.p: "enclosure" in relation to an animal, means any kraal, pen, paddock, cage or other fenced or enclosed area erected to confine an animal from escaping or roaming freely on the remainder of the premises;

item.p: in relation to any animal, the owner of the animal or any other person responsible for feeding and caring for the animal;

in relation to a battery system, cattery, kennels, pet parlour or pet shop means the person who owns the business of which it forms part of and the person in charge of the premises in which the animals are kept;

blockList.listIntroduction: "kennels" means premises in or upon which –

item.p: boarding facilities for dogs are provided;
dogs are bred for commercial purposes;
dogs are kept for the purposes of being trained or hired out with or without handlers; or
dogs are kept for commercial security purposes;

content.p: "livestock" means horses, cattle, sheep, goats, pigs, mules, donkeys and poultry;
"pet" means a domestic animal, bird or poultry kept in a household for companionship or amusement;
"pet parlour" means any premises where beauty treatment is given to pets by washing, drying, brushing, clipping, trimming or by attending to their nails or teeth;
"pet shop" means the premises on which the business of keeping and selling of pets is carried out;
"poultry" means fowls, ducks, muscovy ducks, geese, turkeys, pigeons, peacocks and domestic guinea-fowls;
"poultry house" means any roofed-over building or structure in which poultry is kept, other than one in which a battery system is operated;
"poultry run" means any unroofed wire mesh or other enclosure in which poultry is kept, whether or not it is attached to a poultry house;

"proclaimed township" means an approved township as contemplated in sections 79, 103, 111 and 141(4) of the Town Planning and Townships Ordinance, 1986, (Ordinance No. 15 of 1986), or a township approved in terms of any prior law relating to townships;
"rabbit hutch" means any roofed-over building or structure in which rabbits are kept, other than one in which a battery system is operated;
"rabbit run" means any unroofed wire mesh or other enclosure in which rabbits are kept, whether or not it is attached to a rabbit hutch;
"stable" means any building or structure used to accommodate livestock other than poultry;
"wild animal" means an animal of a species that is not generally domesticated and without limitation includes all animals indigenous to South Africa other than domesticated guinea-fowls.

part.heading: General provisions relating to the keeping of animals

intro.p: Subject to the provisions of subsection (2), the provisions of this Chapter do not apply to -

content.p: any agricultural show where animals are kept on a temporary basis; and
any laboratory where animals are kept for research purposes.
The provisions of section 144 apply to the keeping of animals at any agricultural show and at research laboratory.

No person may, subject to the provisions of section 121, keep or allow to be kept, any animal other than an approved pet on an erf in a proclaimed township, provided the keeping of such pet does not create or constitute a nuisance

intro.p: If at any time it appears to an authorized official that the keeping of poultry or rabbits on an erf or agricultural holding, in respect of which a permit has been granted, is likely to constitute a nuisance or danger to the public health, that official may -

content.p: cancel the permit; or
prohibit the keeping of such poultry or rabbits.

An authorized official must serve a notice on the permit holder or the owner of the erf or agricultural holding concerned, informing him or her of a decision in terms of subsection (4) and instruct the owner to comply with the requirements within the period stated in such notice, which must be at least 48 hours. [Subsection (5) amended: Notice 2076 : 2011-08-03 PG No 167]
An authorized official must as soon as a permit has been cancelled, notify the permit holder of that fact in writing.

An authorized official may, subject to the foregoing provisions of this section, issue a new permit if he is satisfied that the reason for the cancellation no longer exists or that there is no reason why a new permit should not be issued.

part.heading: Keeping of cattle, horses, mules and donkeys

intro.p: No person may keep any cattle, horse, mule or donkey in a stable or enclosure that does not comply with the following requirements:

content.p: Every wall and partition of the stable must be constructed of brick, stone, concrete or other durable material;
the internal wall surfaces of the stable must be constructed of smooth brick or other durable surface brought to a smooth finish;

intro.p: the height of the walls to the wall plates of the stable must –

content.p: if the roof is a pitched roof be 2,4 metres;
if the roof is a flat roof be 2,7 metres;
if the roof is a lean to roof be a mean height of 3 metres with a minimum of 2,4 metres on the lowest side;
in the case of a stable which has an opening along the entire length of one of it’s long sides be not less than 2 metres;
the stable must have a floor area of at least 9 m² for each head of cattle, horse, mule or donkey accommodated in it;

lighting and ventilation must be provided by openings or glazed opening windows or louvers totalling at least 0,3 m² for each animal to be accommodated in it except in the case of a stable open along the entire length of one of its long sides;
the lowest point of every opening, window or louvers must be at least 1,8 metres above floor level;
the floor of the stable must be constructed of concrete or other durable and impervious material brought to a smooth finish graded to a channel and drained in terms of section 143;
any enclosure must have an area of at least 10 m² for each head of cattle, horse, mule or donkey accommodated in it and the fencing must be strong enough to prevent the animals from breaking out;

intro.p: no enclosure or stable may be situated within –

content.p: 15 metres of the boundary of any land, property, dwelling or other structure used for human habitation; or
50 metres of any water resource or water supply intended or used for human consumption; and
there must be a water supply adequate for drinking and cleaning purposes next to every stable or enclosure.

section.heading: Duties of keeper of cattle, horses, mules and donkeys

intro.p: Any person who keeps any cattle, horse, mule or donkey must -

content.p: maintain the premises, and any equipment, apparatus, container or receptacle used in connection with keeping the animal, in a clean and sanitary condition and in good repair;
provide portable manure storage receptacles of an impervious material and with close fitting lids;
keep every manure storage receptacle on a platform constructed of concrete or other durable and impervious material near the stable or enclosure;

intro.p: if there is so much manure and bedding that storage receptacles are impractical, provide a manure container or area complying with the following requirements:

content.p: The manure container or area must be roofed and enclosed by three walls constructed of brick, concrete or other durable material plastered to a smooth finish; and

the floor must be of smoothly finished concrete that is inclined so that it drains to a water channel along the full length of the open side, which is at least 150mm in diameter and is kept filled with water;
remove all the manure from the stable and enclosure at least once every 24 hours and place it in the manure storage receptacles or manure container or area until it is removed from the premises;

remove the contents of the manure storage receptacles or manure container or area from the premises at least once every second day and dispose of the manure in a way which will not create a public health nuisance;
remove all bedding from the stable at least once a week and store it in the manure receptacles or manure container or area until it is removed from the premises;
store all saddles, bridles, harnesses and other equipment or articles used in connection with the keeping of the animals, in a storeroom or other adequate storage facility; and
store all feed in a rodent-proof storeroom and all loose feed in rodent-proof receptacles with close fitting lids.
The provisions of sections 122 and 123 also apply to the temporary keeping of a goat on any premises for the provision of milk for medical reasons.

intro.p: No person may keep goats or sheep in –
an enclosure which does not comply with the following requirements:

content.p: The minimum overall floor area must be 30 m²; and
at least 1,5 m² of floor space must be provided for every goat or sheep accommodated in it; or

intro.p: a stable which does not comply with the following requirements:

content.p: Every wall must be constructed of brick, stone, concrete or other durable material;
every wall must be at least 2 metres in height and have a smooth internal finish;
the floor must be constructed of concrete or other durable and impervious material brought to a smooth finish and graded to a channel drained in terms of section 143;
at least 1,5 m² of floor space must be provided for every goat or sheep accommodated in it with an overall minimum floor area of 6 m²; and
lighting and ventilation openings totalling at least 0,15 m² per goat or sheep must be provided.

intro.p: No person may keep goats or sheep in an enclosure or stable within –

content.p: 15 metres of any boundary of any land, dwelling, building or other structure used for human habitation; or
50 metres of any water resource or water supply intended or used for human consumption.
Every person must provide a water supply adequate for drinking and cleaning purposes situated next to or in every enclosure or stable used to accommodate goats or sheep.

section.heading: Duties of keeper of goats and sheep

intro.p: Any person who keeps goats or sheep must -

content.p: maintain the premises and any equipment, apparatus, container or receptacle used in connection with keeping the animal in a clean and sanitary condition and in good repair;
provide portable manure storage receptacles of an impervious material and with close fitting lids;
keep every manure storage receptacle on a platform that enables the surface underneath the receptacle to be cleaned;
remove all manure from the enclosure or stable at least once every seven days and place it in the manure storage receptacles;
remove the contents of the manure storage receptacles from the premises at least once every seven days and dispose of the manure in a way that will not create a public health nuisance; and
store all feed in a rodent-proof storeroom and all loose feed in rodent-proof receptacles with close fitting lids in the storeroom.
The provisions of sections 126(d), (f), (g) and 127(e), do not apply to any person keeping ten or less poultry.
No person may keep more than 10 poultry on an erf in a proclaimed township or 100 poultry on premises zoned for agricultural purposes except in terms of a permit authorising that activity.

intro.p: No person may keep poultry in premises which do not comply with the following requirements:
In relation to a poultry house –

content.p: every wall must be constructed of brick, stone, concrete or other impervious material and must have a smooth internal surface;
the floor must be constructed of concrete or other impervious material brought to a smooth finish;
the upper floor of a two or more story structure must be constructed of an impervious and easily cleanable material;

intro.p: the minimum floor area must be –

content.p: 0,20 m² for each grown fowl, duck, muscovy duck or guinea fowl;
0,5 m² for each grown goose, turkey or peacock; and
0, 14 m² for each grown pigeon; and
the minimum aggregate floor area must be 4 m²;
a poultry run, if provided, must be enclosed with wire mesh or other durable material;

intro.p: in relation to a building or structure housing a battery system –

content.p: every wall, if provided, must be at least 2,4 m high, must be constructed of concrete, stone, brick or other impervious material and must have a smooth internal surface;

if walls are provided, the building must be ventilated and lighted by means of mechanical ventilation and artificial lighting or by obtaining natural ventilation and light through openings or opening windows of an area not less than 15% of the floor area of the building or structure;

the floor must be constructed of concrete or other impervious material brought to a smooth finish and if required by an environmental health officer, the floor surface must be graded and drained by means of a channel drained in terms of section 143;
if no walls are provided, or the walls are made of metal, the floor must be provided with a curb at least 150 mm high around its edges;
the cages of the battery system must be made of an impervious material; and
if required by an environmental health officer, a tray of an impervious material must be fitted under every cage for the collection of manure;
a water supply adequate for drinking and cleaning must be provided in or next to every poultry house and poultry run and in or next to a building or structure housing a battery system;

intro.p: no poultry house, poultry run, or building or structure housing a battery system, may be constructed within 3 metres of –

content.p: any dwelling or other building or structure used for human habitation; and
any place where foodstuffs are stored or prepared for human consumption;
or (iii) the nearest boundary of any land;
feed must be stored in an adequate rodent-proof storeroom;
adequate washing facilities must be provided for the cleaning of the cages;

intro.p: if required by an environmental health officer, due to the amount of manure stored on the premises awaiting removal, a storage area complying with the following requirements must be provided:

content.p: A roofed platform constructed of concrete or other impervious material;
the platform’s outside edges must have a minimum curb of 100 mm high;
the platform must be graded and drained in terms of section 143; and
the roof of the platform must extend a minimum of 1 metre beyond the edges of the base of the platform.

intro.p: Any person who keeps poultry must -

content.p: ensure that all poultry is kept within a poultry house, poultry run or building or structure housing a battery system;
maintain the premises and any equipment, apparatus, container or receptacle used in connection with keeping the poultry, in a clean, sanitary condition and in good repair;
maintain the premises and every poultry house, poultry run or building or structure housing a battery system and all cages clean and free from pests;
ensure that the poultry do not disturb or hinder the comfort, convenience, peace or quiet of the public;
provide portable manure storage receptacles of an impervious material and with close fitting lids and keep the manure storage receptacles on a platform;
remove all manure and other waste from a poultry house and poultry run at least once every 48 hours and once every four days from a building or structure housing a battery system;
place the manure and other waste matter in manure storage receptacles;
remove the contents of the manure storage receptacles from the premises at least once every seven days and dispose of the manure in a way which will not create a public health nuisance; and
take adequate measures to keep the premises free of flies, cockroaches and rodents and to prevent offensive odours arising from the keeping of poultry on the premises.
The provisions of sections 130(b), (c), (d), (f) and (g), and 131(d), (f) and (g), do not apply to any person keeping ten or less rabbits.

No person may keep more than 5 adult rabbits on an erf in a proclaimed township or more than 20 adult rabbits on premises zoned for agricultural purposes, except in terms of a permit authorising that activity.

intro.p: No person may keep rabbits in premises which do not comply with the following requirements:
In relation to a rabbit hutch -

content.p: every wall must be constructed of brick, stone, concrete or other impervious material and must have a smooth internal surface;

intro.p: the floor surface must be –

content.p: constructed of concrete or other impervious material brought to a smooth finish;
situated at least 150 mm above ground level; and
graded to a channel drained in terms of section 143, if required by an environmental health officer;
adequate ventilation must be provided; and
the rabbit hutch must be adequate in size to allow free unobstructed movement of animals kept therein.
any rabbit run must be enclosed with wire mesh or other durable material and constructed in a way that prevents the escape of rabbits from the run;

intro.p: in relation to a building or structure housing a battery system –
every wall must –

content.p: be at least 2,4 metres high;
be constructed of concrete, stone, brick or other durable material; and
must have a smooth internal surface;
if walls are provided, the building or structure must be ventilated and lighted by means of natural openings or windows of an area not less than 15% of the floor area of the building or structure;

the floor must be constructed of concrete or other impervious material brought to a smooth finish, and if required by an environmental health officer, the floor surface must be graded to a channel drained in terms of section 143;
if no walls are provided, or the walls are made of metal, the floor must be provided with a curb at least 150 mm high around its outside edges; and
every cage must be constructed of an impervious material and fitted with trays of an impervious material for the reception of manure;
a water supply adequate for drinking and cleaning purposes must be provided in or next to every rabbit hutch or building or structure housing a battery system;

intro.p: no person may erect a rabbit hutch, rabbit run or building or structure housing a battery system within five metres of –

content.p: any dwelling, building or other structure used for human habitation;
any place where foodstuffs are stored or prepared for human consumption; or
the nearest boundary of any land;
an adequate rodent-proof storeroom must be provided for the storage of feed; and
adequate washing facilities must be provided for the cleaning of cages.

intro.p: Any person who keeps rabbits must -

content.p: keep all rabbits within the rabbit hutch, rabbit run or building or structure housing a battery system;
maintain the premises and any equipment, apparatus, containers or receptacles used in connection with keeping rabbits, in a clean, sanitary condition and in good repair;
maintain the premises free from offensive odours and every rabbit hutch, rabbit run or building or structure housing a battery system and all cages clean and free from pests;
provide portable manure storage receptacles of an impervious material with close-fitting lids which receptacles must be kept on a platform;
remove all manure and any other waste matter from the rabbit hutch, rabbit run or building or structure housing a battery system, at least once every 48 hours;
keep the manure and waste in manure storage receptacles until it is removed from the premises; and
remove the contents of the manure storage receptacles from the premises at least once every seven days and dispose of the contents in a way which will not create a public health nuisance.

part.heading: Keeping of birds other than poultry

intro.p: No person may keep any bird, other than poultry, in an aviary which does not comply with the following requirements:

content.p: the aviary must be constructed of durable rodent-proof material;
adequate access must be provided for cleaning purposes;
if the aviary is constructed above ground level, its base must be constructed of an impervious and durable material and must be situated a minimum of 300 mm above ground level;
the aviary may not be situated within three metres of any building or structure, boundary fence or boundary wall; and
a water supply adequate for drinking and cleaning purposes must be situated in or next to every aviary.

intro.p: Any person who keeps birds in an aviary must -

content.p: ensure that the aviary and the premises are kept in a clean condition and free from pests;
provide and use rodent-proof facilities for the storage of bird food; and
ensure that the birds do not disturb the comfort, convenience, peace or quiet of the public.

intro.p: No person may use premises as kennels or a cattery except in terms of a permit authorising that activity and unless the premises comply with the following requirements:
Every dog or cat must be kept in an enclosure which complies with the following requirements:

content.p: the enclosure must be constructed of impervious materials and must provide adequate access for cleaning purposes;

the floor must be constructed of concrete or other impervious material brought to a smooth finish and graded to a channel 100 mm wide, extending the full width of the floor, which channel must be graded and drained into a gully connected to the Council’s sewer by means of a pipe 100 mm in diameter; and
a curb 150 mm high must be provided along the edge of the channel, referred to in subparagraph (ii), to prevent any storm water runoff entering the channel; and
the enclosure must be adequate in size to allow free unobstructed movement of animals kept therein.

intro.p: subject to the provisions of paragraph (c), every enclosure referred to in paragraph (a), must be provided with an adequate roofed shelter that complies with the following requirements:

content.p: Every wall must be made of brick, stone, concrete or other impervious material;
every wall must have a smooth internal surface;
the floor must be made of concrete or other impervious material brought to a smooth finish; and
every shelter must have adequate access for cleaning and eliminating pests;

intro.p: a dog kennel which complies with the following requirements may be provided instead of the shelter contemplated in paragraph (b):

content.p: The kennel must be constructed of an approved weatherproof and insulating material or other similar material;
the kennel must be movable;
the kennel must be placed on a base constructed of concrete or other impervious material with an easily cleanable finish; and
a sleeping board, which will enable the dog to keep dry, must be provided in any kennel that does not have a waterproof base;
a concrete apron extending at least one metre wide around the edges of the enclosure must be provided;
the apron must be graded and drained in a way that drains storm water away from the enclosure;
a water supply, adequate for drinking and cleaning purposes, must be provided in or adjacent to the enclosure;
any cage in which cats are kept must be constructed of durable impervious material and in a manner that it may be easily cleaned; and

intro.p: no shelter, enclosure or kennel may be situated within five metres of any –

content.p: dwelling or other building or structure used for human habitation;
place where food is stored and prepared for human consumption; or
the boundary of the premises.

intro.p: Any keeper of kennels or a cattery who is so instructed by an environmental health officer, must provide a separate room or roofed area for the preparation of food which complies with the following requirements:

content.p: The floor of the room or roofed area must be constructed of concrete or other impervious material brought to a smooth finish;
the internal wall surfaces of the room or roofed area must be smooth and easily cleanable;
adequate washing facilities for food bowls and utensils must be provided; and
a rodent-proof storeroom must be provided for the storage of food.

section.heading: Duties of a keepers of kennels or catteries

intro.p: Any person operating kennels or a cattery must –

content.p: maintain the premises, equipment and every vessel, receptacle or container and sleeping board used in connection with the kennels or cattery in a clean, sanitary condition and in good repair;
provide portable storage receptacles, of an impervious material with close fitting lids, for the storage of dog and cat faeces;

remove all faeces and other waste matter from the enclosure and shelter at least once every 24 hours and place it in the receptacles referred to in paragraph (b); (d) remove the contents of the storage receptacles from the premises at least twice every seven days and dispose of it in a manner that will not create a public health nuisance;
store all loose food in receptacles, with close fitting lids, in the food store;
provide adequate refrigeration facilities to store perishable foods on the premises;
provide adequate separate refuse receptacles, with close fitting lids, on the premises for refuse other than faeces;
keep any sick dog or cat isolated from any other animals; and
maintain the premises free from offensive odours and every enclosure, shelter, kennel, cage or food store clean and free from pests.
ensure that no dog or cat disturbs the comfort, convenience, peace and quiet of the public.

intro.p: No person may operate a pet shop or pet parlour in or on any premises which do not comply with the following requirements:
Any wall and partition must –

content.p: be constructed of brick, concrete or other impervious material;
have a smooth and easily cleanable internal surface; and
be painted with a washable paint or other adequate finish;
all floor surfaces must be constructed of concrete or other impervious material brought to a smooth finish;
all ceilings must be dust proof and easily cleanable;

at least one wash hand basin, with a supply of running hot and cold potable water, must be provided for employees and the ratio of wash hand basins to persons employed on the premises must not be less than 1:15; (e) the wash hand basins, referred to in subparagraph (d), must be drained in terms of section 143;
adequate storage facilities must be provided;

intro.p: facilities for the washing of cages, trays and other equipment must be provided in the form of either –

content.p: a curbed and roofed over platform with a minimum surface area of 1,5 m², raised at least 100 mm above the floor and constructed of concrete or other impervious material brought to a smooth finish, which platform must be provided with a supply of running potable water; or
a stainless steel sink or trough of adequate size with a drainage board and provided with a supply of running potable water;
the platform, sink or trough referred to in paragraph (g) must be drained in terms of section 143;

any wall surface within 0,5 metres of the platform, sink or trough referred to in paragraph (g), must be permanently covered with waterproof material to a minimum height of 1,4 metres above the floor;

intro.p: a clearly designated changeroom must be provided if more than six persons are employed on the premises and every change room must –

content.p: have a floor area providing at least 0,5 m² for each employee;
have a minimum overall floor area of 6 m² and width of two metres; and
be equipped with an adequate metal locker for each employee;
if no changeroom is required in terms of paragraph (j), each employee must be provided with an adequate metal locker;

intro.p: for the purposes of washing, clipping or grooming of pets –

content.p: a bathroom fitted with a bath, or similar fitting, and a wash hand basin supplied with running potable water must be provided;

a clipping and grooming room fitted with impervious topped tables and an adequate number of portable storage receptacles of an impervious durable material with close fitting lids, for the storage of cut hair pending removal, must be provided;
at least 50 % of the floor area of the rooms referred to in subparagraphs (i) and (ii), must be unobstructed; and
the floors of the rooms referred to in subparagraphs (i) and (ii), must be graded to a channel drained in terms of section 143;
all buildings, including storage areas, must be rodent-proof; and

intro.p: the premises may not have direct internal access with any room or place –

content.p: used for human habitation;
where clothing is stored or sold; or
where food is prepared, stored or sold for human consumption.

section.heading: Duties of pet shop or pet parlour keepers

intro.p: Any keeper of a pet shop or pet parlour must –
provide cages for housing the pets which comply with the following requirements:

content.p: the cages must be constructed of metal or other impervious material and fitted with a removable metal floor-tray to facilitate cleaning;
the exterior cavity of any tubular or hollow material used to construct a cage must be sealed;
the cages must be able to be moved easily;
where rabbits are kept in a cage, the metal floor-tray referred to in subparagraph (i), must be drained to a removable receptacle;
the cages must be fitted with a drinking vessel filled with water;
the distance from any cage to the nearest wall must be a minimum of 150 mm; (vii) the cages must be kept a minimum of 450 mm above floor level; and
the space below every cage must be unobstructed;
provide rodent-proof receptacles, of an impervious material and with close fitting lids, for the storage of all loose pet food in the storage facilities required in terms of section 137 (f);
provide adequate refrigeration facilities to store all perishable pet food on the premises;

intro.p: ensure that in any room in which the pets are kept –

content.p: 50 % of the floor space is unobstructed; and
the cages are placed a minimum of 800 mm from one another;

maintain the premises and every cage, tray, container, receptacle, basket and all apparatus, equipment or appliances used in connection with the pet shop or pet palour, in a clean and sanitary condition, free from pests and in good repair;
provide overalls or other protective clothing for employees and ensure that the employees wear them when on duty;
provide isolation facilities in which every pet which is, or appears to be, sick must be kept while on the premises;
provide an adequate supply of potable water for drinking and cleaning purposes;
provide adequate ventilation to ensure the comfort and survival of the pets; and
ensure that the number of pets contained in each cage does not impede their free movement.

intro.p: No person may, without the approval of the relevant nature conservation authorities, keep wild animals on premises which do not comply with the following requirements:
Every wild animal must be kept in an enclosure and/or housing constructed and equipped as follows:

content.p: The enclosure and/or housing must satisfy the needs of the specific animal as specified by the relevant nature conservation authorities;

intro.p: the enclosure and/or housing may not be situated within 50 metres of –

content.p: any boundary of the premises;
any dwelling, building or structure used for human habitation;
any dwelling, building or structure where food is stored, handled or prepared for human consumption; or
any water resource intended for domestic consumption;
an adequate supply of potable water for drinking and cleaning purposes must be provided; and
the enclosure and/or housing must be graded and drained in a way that does not pollute any water resource or create a public health nuisance;
a separate room, equipped with a preparation table and wash-up sink, supplied with running potable water and drained in accordance with section 143, must be provided for the preparation of food;

intro.p: adequate facilities must be provided for washing any cages, trays, crates, refuse receptacles and food containers in the form of either –

content.p: a curbed platform constructed of concrete or other impervious material brought to a smooth finish; or
a stainless steel sink or trough adequate in size to accommodate the equipment to be washed;
both facilities referred to in paragraph (c) must be provided with a supply of running water adequate for drinking and cleaning and be drained in accordance with section 143;
any area and room in which fodder and food are stored must be rodent-proof; and
the enclosure and/or housing must be adequate in size to allow free unobstructed movement of animals kept therein.

section.heading: Duties of keepers of wild animals

intro.p: Any person who keeps wild animals must –

content.p: maintain the premises in a clean and sanitary condition at all times;
clean all manure and food scraps from any enclosure and/or housing at adequate intervals;
prevent the soil beneath or around any enclosure and/or housing from becoming saturated with urine or polluted by any other matter or liquid; and
remove all bedding from any housing at least once every seven days and store it in a manure receptacle or manure container or area, until it is removed from the premises.

intro.p: No person may keep pigs on premises which do not comply with the following requirements:
Every wall must –

content.p: be constructed of brick, stone, concrete or other durable material;
have a minimum height of 1,5 metres; and
have a smooth, impervious internal surface;
the floor area must provide at least 3 m² for each pig accommodated in the pigsty, with an overall minimum floor area of 6 m²;
the roof over any portion of a pigsty must have a minimum height of 1,5 metres;

intro.p: except in the case of a roofed structure having one of its long sides completely open, the lighting and ventilation openings must –

content.p: be situated opposite one another in the external walls; and
provide a minimum of 0,15 m² for each pig;

intro.p: the floor must be –

content.p: at least 150 mm above the surrounding ground level;
constructed of concrete or other durable and impervious material brought to a smooth finish; and
graded for the run-off of liquids into an open channel outside the pigsty;

intro.p: the open channel referred to in paragraph (e)(iii) must –

content.p: be constructed of concrete or other durable and impervious material;
be a minimum of 100 mm in diameter; and
be drained in terms of section 143;
the pigsty must be strong enough to prevent the pigs breaking out;

intro.p: the pigsty may not be situated within 100 metres of –

content.p: the boundary of the premises;
any dwelling, building or structure used for human habitation;
any place where foodstuffs are stored or prepared for human consumption; or
any water resource intended for domestic consumption;

intro.p: a roofed over concrete platform must be provided for –

content.p: the storage of all swill in containers; and
the preparation of pig feed;
the platform referred to in paragraph (i) must comply with the provisions of paragraph (e) and in addition, must have a curbing of a minimum height of 100 mm on each edge; and
a water supply, adequate for drinking and cleaning purposes, must be provided in or adjacent to the pigsty.

intro.p: Every person keeping pigs must -

content.p: ensure that every pig is kept within a pigsty;
maintain the premises and any equipment, apparatus, containers and receptacles concerned in a clean and sanitary condition and in good repair;
provide portable storage receptacles, of impervious material and with close fitting lids, to store manure;
keep all manure storage receptacles on a platform that complies with the provisions of section 141 (j);
remove all manure from the pigsty at least once every 24 hours and place it in the manure storage receptacles;
remove the contents of the manure storage receptacles from the premises at least once every second day and dispose of the manure in a manner that will not create a public health nuisance;
provide a rodent-proof store-room of adequate size in which all feed, other than swill, must be stored; and
provide rodent-proof receptacles, with close fitting lids, in which to store all loose feed.

Any person keeping animals must ensure that all sinks, wash hand basins, baths, shower-baths, troughs, floor surfaces, channels and washing platforms required to be drained in terms of this Chapter, are drained in accordance with the provisions of the National Building Regulations and Building Standards Act.

No person may without a permit issued by an environmental health officer, keep any wild animal of a species that is dangerous to humans, including without limitation, large carnivores, venomous snakes, spiders or scorpions.

Any person who keeps any animal which is known to behave in a manner that is dangerous to humans must keep it in an adequate enclosure and take adequate measures to ensure that it does not escape from the enclosure or pose a danger to the residents of, or visitors to, the premises or any other person.

intro.p: No person may keep bees on any premises unless –

content.p: that person is the holder of a permit authorising that activity; and

intro.p: every bee hive is situated –

content.p: a minimum of five metres from any boundary of the premises; and
a minimum of twenty metres from any public place or building used for human habitation or from any place used for the keeping of animals, poultry and birds;
the bees are kept in an approved bee hive; and

intro.p: the bee hive is –

content.p: kept in an area inaccessible to children and animals;
…… [[Section 145(1)(d)(ii) deleted : Notice: 5319: 5/12/07, PG 347]]
supplied with a source of drinking water within five metres of the hive.
No person may dump or deposit any garbage, compost, grass cuttings or manure within five metres of any bee hive.
Bees must at all times be kept strictly in accordance with the Council’s guidelines for the keeping of bees.

section.heading: Illness attributable to animals, poultry or birds

content.p: The illness of any person, which may be attributed to any animal, poultry or bird kept or handled by that person, must be reported to an environmental health officer within 24 hours of diagnosis, by the person making the diagnosis.

An environmental health officer may order the removal of an animal, poultry or bird from premises if he or she reasonably believes that the animal poses a public health nuisance or public health hazard.

section.heading: Keeping of and slaughtering animals for religious and ceremonial purposes

content.p: Any person who keeps an animal prior to slaughtering it for any religious or ceremonial purposes, must comply with the provisions of this Chapter applicable to the animal concerned.

intro.p: A person intending to slaughter an animal in any place other than in a recognised abattoir must -

content.p: notify the Council in writing, fourteen days prior to the event;
slaughter the animal in a position where the slaughtering cannot be observed by any person on neighbouring premises or any member of the public;
use the meat derived from the slaughtered animal solely for the purposes of the religious or ceremonial feast;
handle the meat in a hygienic manner at all times;
dispose of any portions of the animal which are not used or consumed, in a manner which will not become a public health hazard or public health nuisance; and
not keep such animal prior to slaughtering for a period in excess of 24 hours.

section.heading: Introduction of milk and milk products into the Municipal Area

intro.p: No person is allowed to introduce, unless for own consumption, into the municipal area any milk or milk product for purposes of human consumption unless-

content.p: that person is the holder of a permit;
such milk or milk product is pasteurised or otherwise treated to render it safe for human consumption before offered for sale to the public.
In this Chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates, any word or expression to which a meaning has been assigned in the Act shall have the meaning so assigned and –
"Act or the Act" means Child Care Act, 1983 including the regulations made in terms of section 60 thereof;
"adopted child" means a child adopted under the provisions of Chapter 4 of the Act;
"adoptive parent" means a person who adopts or has adopted a child under the provisions of Chapter 4 of the Act;
"child" means any person under the age of 18 years and "children" has a corresponding meaning;

"children’s home" means any residence or home maintained for the reception, protection, care and bringing-up of more than six children living apart from their parents, guardian or person in whose custody the child is, but does not include any school of industries or reform school, with the understanding that separate living accommodation can be provided on the children’s home premises where a parent, guardian or person in whose custody the child is will be living together with such a child;

"family" means parent, guardian or person in whose custody the child is or was, immediately before commencement of any proceedings for the alternative placement of the child and also includes any parent, guardian or person in whose custody the child is and who is living in separate accommodation on the premises of a children’s home;
"parent" means natural or adoptive parent;
"person in charge" refers to the owner, the principal or any person who is in effective control of the children’s home whether permanently or temporarily;
"prophylaxis" means preventative treatment against disease;
"play area" means a separate area identified for children to play;
"staff member" means a person employed by the children's home on a temporary or permanent basis.
No person shall operate a children’s home except in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter and in terms of a permit authorising the operation of a children's home.

section.heading: General provisions for children’s home premises

intro.p: A children’s home may only be operated on premises which are located, designed, constructed, finished and equipped in such a condition that children –

content.p: can be cared for hygienically;
can be adequately protected against any possible public health hazard and public health nuisance;
can be adequately fed;
are provided with adequate shelter;
have access to potable clean water;
can be adequately safeguarded from any condition which may impact on their safety; and
are not allowed access to any accommodation set aside exclusively for the use of staff.

intro.p: Premises from which a children's home is operated shall have the following-

separate living quarters for staff members and families living on the premises, which comply with the provisions of Chapter 10 of these by-laws, dealing with accommodation establishments, whether services are rendered for gain or not, provided that living quarters make separate provision for sleeping accommodation for:

content.p: any guardian and child;
any person in whose custody the child is and the child; and
the different sexes for children 7 years and older;
separate approved toilet and hand wash facilities for staff members, as contemplated in the National Building Regulations and Building Standards Act;
separate designated change and storage facilities of adequate size for the storage of the personal belongings of staff members;
an adequate office area; and
an adequate kitchen area, where food is to be handled and provided to children which complies with any relevant laws.

intro.p: Indoor areas complying with the following requirements shall be provided-
For children under the age of two years:

content.p: sleeping accommodation of 2m² per child;
an adequate separate facility for the hygienic preparation and storage of milk and milk formulas;
an adequate separate facility for the hygienic washing, sterilisation and storage of feeding bottles, cups and other containers;
the facilities contemplated in sections 152 (1) (a) (ii) and (iii) can form part of any kitchen on the premises and shall comply with any relevant laws;
a separate napkin changing unit with an impervious work surface for changing the napkins of children;
adequate hand wash and bathing facilities to clean children when changing napkins;
the facilities referred to in sections 152 (1) (a) (v) and (vi) shall be cleaned after each use and clean water and clean cloths shall be used for each washing procedure;
adequate impervious containers with a tight fitting lid for the storage of soiled napkins;
separate, approved storage facility for the storage of clean napkins;
adequate storage facilities for the storage of personal belongings and clothing of each child;
adequate toilet and hand wash facilities as contemplated in section 154 hereof;
adequate separate storage facilities for clean and dirty linen and bedding;
a separate safe sleeping facility provided with an approved mattress of impervious material and bedding for each child, with a minimum distance of 750mm between sleeping facilities;
each cot, bed, linen or bedding shall only be used by a single child and shall be cleaned and sanitised before being assigned to another child.

intro.p: For children between two to six years of age:

content.p: sleeping accommodation of 2m² per child;
adequate separate storage facilities for the storage of personal belongings and clothing of each child;
adequate bathing, hand wash and toilet facilities as contemplated in sections 154 and 155 hereof;
adequate separate storage facilities for clean and dirty linen and bedding;
a separate safe sleeping facility provided with an approved mattress and bedding for each child, with a minimum distance of 750mm between sleeping facilities; and

intro.p: For children between seven to thirteen years of age:

content.p: sleeping accommodation of 4m² per child separate for the sexes;
adequate separate and private storage facilities for the storage of personal belongings and clothing of each child;
adequate bathing, hand wash and toilet facilities as contemplated in sections 154 and 155 hereof;
adequate separate storage facilities for clean and dirty linen and bedding;
a separate safe sleeping facility provided with an approved mattress and bedding for each child with a minimum distance of 750mm between sleeping facilities;
sanitary towels tampons and facilities for the safe disposal after use.

intro.p: For children above the age of thirteen years:

content.p: sleeping accommodation of 4m² per child separate for the sexes;
adequate separate, private and lockable storage facilities for the storage of personal belongings and clothing of each child;
adequate bathing, hand wash and toilet facilities as contemplated in sections 154 and 155 hereof;
adequate storage facility for clean and dirty linen and bedding;
separate safe sleeping facility provided with an approved mattress and bedding for each child, with a minimum distance of 750 mm between sleeping facilities; and
sanitary towels and tampons and facilities for the safe disposal after use.

intro.p: Indoor activity and play areas

content.p: Separate indoor activity and play areas of 1,5m² per child shall be provided for the following age categories:
Under 2 years of age; 2 to 6 years; 7 years and older;
unless arrangements are made and a roster instituted to regulate times the activity and play area can be used separately by the age groups contemplated in subsection (i);
The indoor play and activity areas referred to in subsection (i) shall be increased by 1,5m² unobstructed floor space per child, where no outdoor play or activity areas have been provided.
Adequate child-sized seating and tables for each child two to six years of age shall be provided in the indoor play or activity area.
Adequate seating and tables for each child seven years and older shall be provided in the indoor play or activity area.
An approved facility for the disinfecting of toys and other equipment shall be provided.
Adequate indoor and outdoor play equipment for the children’s use shall be provided.

intro.p: If a children’s home premises has an outdoor play or activity area it must –

content.p: be free of any excavations, steps, projections, levels or any surface which may adversely impact on the health and safety of children using that area;
provide a minimum outdoor area of 2m² per child;
have an adequate means of enclosure and a lockable gate to prevent a child from leaving the premises on his or her own and to prevent the entrance of any animal and unauthorised person; and

intro.p: have separate outdoor play or activity areas for the following age categories of children:

content.p: Under 2 years;
2 to 6 years;
7 years and older.

intro.p: In the event that adequate space is not available to cater for a separate outdoor play area as contemplated in Section 153(1)(d) above, the following shall occur -

content.p: a roster regulating different times for the use of the play area by different age groups should be instituted; or alternatively
adequate supervision should be provided, to ensure the safety of each child using the outdoor play area, at all times.

intro.p: A children’s home premises shall be provided with the following-

content.p: toilets at a ratio of not more than 15 children for each toilet or chemical toilet;
hand wash facilities at a ratio of not more than 20 children for each hand wash facility; and

a supply of hot and cold running potable water must be available at every wash hand basin, or if no running water is available, a minimum of 25 litres of potable water, stored in a hygienically clean container, must be available at each wash hand basin .

intro.p: A children’s home premises shall be provided with the following-

content.p: a bath for every 8 children separate for the sexes and designated accordingly;

intro.p: showers may be substituted for baths in the following ratios:

content.p: Males – two thirds of total number of baths; and
Females – one third of total number of baths.

a supply of hot and cold running potable water at every bath and shower facility, or if no running water is available, a minimum of 25 litres of potable water stored in a hygienically clean container must be available at each bath or shower.

intro.p: Any person who operates or is in charge of a children’s home must –

content.p: provide an adequate first aid area with adequate and appropriate first aid equipment for the treatment of minor ailments and bodily injuries sustained by children;
have an accessible list of emergency contact numbers which shall include fire brigade, ambulance, outbreak response, clinic, hospital, doctor and police;
be trained in basic first aid;

ensure that adequate provision is made for disposable gloves and disinfectants to protect staff and children, and also to disinfect contaminated areas and surfaces when dealing with blood related illness and injuries;
ensure that immediately after treating a child with blood related illnesses and injuries, areas and surfaces where treatment took place are adequately disinfected;
ensure that post exposure prophylaxis for HIV and Hepatitis B be made available to any child or caregiver who may have been so exposed;

intro.p: in respect of any child who becomes ill or has suffered an injury requiring medical attention, –

content.p: immediately transport such child to the nearest clinic or hospital or call for medical assistance;
ensure that appropriate medical care is given to the child in the sick bay area, if the illness or injury is not of a nature requiring attendance at the clinic or hospital; and
immediately notify the Council in the event of the illness being a notifiable disease;
ensure that every child has a road to health card and has completed basic immunization schedules as required by the Department of Health;
take measures to adequately manage communicable diseases;
isolate in an approved manner, any child that is suffering from any infectious disease until such time that the disease no longer poses any threat; and

in respect of terminally ill children cared for on the premises, provide approved facilities complying with the requirements contemplated in sections 82, 86 and 91 of Chapter 13 of these by-laws, dealing with Nursing homes.

intro.p: Any person who operates a children’s home must ensure that –

content.p: a room or cupboard of adequate size, is set aside to be used solely for the storage of medicines and drugs; and
every room or cupboard set aside in terms of paragraph (a) above, is kept locked at all times except when medicines or drugs are being removed from it or returned to it.

Any person who provides an after-school care service for children of school-going age other than the children accommodated in the children’s home shall comply with the requirements contemplated in section 108 of Chapter 14 of these by-laws pertaining to child care services.

intro.p: If laundering is carried out on the premises of a children’s home, this activity must take place in accordance with the following provisions –

content.p: a work-room or area used for housing washing-machines, irons, ironing boards, presses and other fixed or movable equipment, with a minimum floor area of 6 m² or 2,5 m² unobstructed floor space per person employed in the laundry, whichever is the greater size, must be provided;

all internal walls must be constructed and finished so as to render them non-absorbent in a manner consistent with the provisions of the National Building Regulations and Building Standards Act, and painted with a lightcoloured washable paint;
all ceilings must be dust-proof, smoothly finished, and painted with a light-coloured washable paint;

all floor surfaces must be constructed of cement or other non-absorbent material brought to a smooth finish in a manner consistent with the provisions of the National Building Regulations and Building Standards Act;
lighting and ventilation as contemplated in the National Building Regulations and Building Standards Act must be provided;
adequate separate facilities for the receiving of dirty laundry and dispatch of clean laundry must be provided;
a store-room or facility for the storage of all relevant materials must be provided and equipped with adequate packing shelves of which the lowest shelf must be at least 250 mm above floor level;
a separate pre-rinsing area must be provided on any premises where nappies are laundered; and
the laundry area must be inaccessible to any child and must at all times be kept locked when not in use.

intro.p: A person in charge of a children’s home must ensure that the following safety measures are complied with-

content.p: children must be adequately protected against fires, hot water installations, electrical fittings and appliances, heating appliances and any other article, thing or substance that may be dangerous or cause injury to any child;

any slats or rails forming part of an enclosure, security gate, play pen, bed, cot or any other object or structure whatsoever must be a maximum of 75 mm apart, must be installed and maintained in a good state of repair, and if painted, only non-toxic paint must be used;
all pesticides, detergents and other harmful substances must be stored in a locked place inaccessible to any child at all times;
no noxious or poisonous or dangerous plant or shrub may be permitted on the premises;

no animals or birds may be kept on the premises unless an approved area, complying with the requirements of Chapter 15 of these by-laws relating to the keeping of animals, is provided, separately from the indoor and outdoor activity and play areas;
no paddling pool, swimming pool or other structure may be permitted in any children’s home without adequate fencing and a safety net;
any sandpit must be adequately covered when not in use and must be treated with a treatment agent on a regular basis;
all toys for children under the age of three years shall be free from any small parts and if painted, only with non-toxic paint;

no person known or suspected to be suffering from an infectious or contagious disease, and no person so suffering, may be allowed to enter the premises or may be employed in the children’s home if in the opinion of an environmental health practitioner, the person is capable of communicating the infectious or contagious disease to the children;

any other reasonable measures which may, in the opinion of an environmental health practitioner, be necessary to protect the children from any physical danger, must be taken by the children’s home service provider on the instruction of an environmental health practitioner.

section.heading: Duties of the person in charge of a children’s home

intro.p: Any person who operates a children’s home must –

content.p: ensure that the children are properly cared for and supervised at all times;
maintain every part of the premises, including any equipment, linen, bedding, feeding utensils and play equipment in good repair and in a clean and hygienic condition at all times;
ensure that all staff members and care givers at the premises are at all times healthy and clean;
ensure that no person smokes or uses any tobacco product in the presence of children or in any area prohibited by the Tobacco Products Control Act, 1993 and regulations published thereunder;

ensure that the toys, books and other indoor play materials intended for day-to-day use are available in any indoor activity or play area and suitably stored so that they are within easy reach of the children;

intro.p: ensure that children are at all times appropriately supervised by an adult when utilizing the indoor and/or outdoor areas -

content.p: one adult supervisor for every 6 children under the age of 2 years;
one adult supervisor for every 15 children aged 2 to 6 years old;
one adult supervisor for every 20 children 7 years and older.

intro.p: in the event that transport to or from a children’s home is provided, ensure that –

content.p: the children are supervised by at least one adult apart from the driver during transportation;
the child locks, if any, and doors of the vehicle are locked so that they cannot be opened from inside the vehicle;
no children are transported in the front seat or the boot of the vehicle;
no children are placed under the seat of a vehicle;
the vehicle is not overloaded in terms of South African traffic laws;
the driver of the vehicle holds a valid driver's licence / permit to transport the passengers;
the vehicle has all relevant permits and documentation to transport the children, is licensed and is in a road worthy condition; and
when transporting children in the back of an enclosed light commercial vehicle, ensure that no exhaust fumes enter the enclosed area and that it is adequately ventilated;
display a weekly menu that must be visible to any visitor;
ensure that children are at all material times under adequate adult supervision when utilizing the sleeping facility;
observe dietary requirements for children with special dietary requirements;
provide nutritionally balanced meals of adequate volume to satisfy the energy and nutritional needs of the children in each age group;
provide an adequate number of bins with liners for the disposal of paper, paper towels, tissues and other waste materials, inside the premises;
provide an approved refuse area, with adequate refuse bins, for the storage of refuse pending removal;
provide each child with a towel for his or her individual use on the premises;
provide adequate individually marked pegs or hooks for each child to hang his or her towel on;
handle and dispose of medical risk waste in accordance with the relevant legislation governing this category;
provide an adequate and easily available supply of toilet paper at all toilets, soap and disposable towelling at all hand wash basins and soap at all baths and/or showers;
ensure that mattresses are cleaned and sanitised when soiled or wet;
ensure that toys are disinfected daily and immediately after it becomes contaminated by body secretions, sputum, blood or by any other means;
ensure that toys are not used simultaneously by children suffering from any infectious disease and healthy children;

ensure that blood spills or spills of other fluids containing blood are removed by using gloves to prevent contamination of the hands and that the contaminated area be disinfected with a freshly prepared solution of 1:10 household bleach and clean water applied to the area for at least 30 seconds and thereafter wiped with disposable material or alternatively by using any other approved and appropriate disinfectant;
provide each child with his or her own toiletry which shall include amongst others, toothbrush, toothpaste, bathing soap, skin lotion and other necessary items required for use by the child; and
provide an adequate supply of tissues for use by the children.

Any person who operates a children’s home must keep an admission and discharge register ("register") of all children admitted to and discharged from the children’s home in accordance with regulation 33 of the Regulations promulgated in Government Gazette 10546 of 12 December 1986 in terms of the provisions of section 60 of the Act.

intro.p: The following particulars where applicable shall be entered in the register –

content.p: his or her full name, sex, date of birth, identity number; names, addresses and telephone numbers of parent or parents, guardian or guardians or next of kin;
date of admission;
